Line 58: Line 58:
==Contemporary Hebrew literature==
==Contemporary Hebrew literature==
{{main|Israeli literature}}
{{main|Israeli literature}}
â
[[File:Yehuda amichai.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Yehuda Amichai]]]]
  â  
A new generation of Hebrew writers emerged with the establishment of the [[State of Israel]] in 1948. This new generation included the novelists [[Aharon Megged]], [[Nathan Shaham]], and [[Moshe Shamir]], and the poets [[Yehudah Amichai]], [[Amir Gilboa]], and [[Haim Gouri]]. The novels ''My Michael'' (1968) and ''Black Box'' (1987) by [[Amos Oz]] and ''The Lover'' (1977) and ''Mr. Mani'' (1990) by [[A. B. Yehoshua]] describe life in the new state. These works also explore topics such the as [[Generation gap|conflict between parents and children]] and the rejection of some once-sacred ideals of [[Judaism]] and [[Zionism]].
A new generation of Hebrew writers emerged with the establishment of the [[State of Israel]] in 1948. This new generation included the novelists [[Aharon Megged]], [[Nathan Shaham]], and [[Moshe Shamir]], and the poets [[Yehudah Amichai]], [[Amir Gilboa]], and [[Haim Gouri]]. The novels ''My Michael'' (1968) and ''Black Box'' (1987) by [[Amos Oz]] and ''The Lover'' (1977) and ''Mr. Mani'' (1990) by [[A. B. Yehoshua]] describe life in the new state. These works also explore topics such the as [[Generation gap|conflict between parents and children]] and the rejection of some once-sacred ideals of [[Judaism]] and [[Zionism]].
